DOC.HEAD: Photographer Who Fought For Nudist Rights Named to Unclad Hall of Fame
DOC.TEXT: A photographer who led a fight to legalize nudity on private property and spurred Kodak into returning snapshots of naked subjects has been inducted into the Nudist Hall of Fame. Ed Lange, 69, was ``utterly delighted'' with the American Sunbathing Association's decision to place him on the 25-year-old honors list, said Chris Moran, spokesman for the Elysium Fields nude resort that Lange founded. ``It is a great honor from his perspective,'' Moran said Tuesday. ``He has basically stuck his neck out for some 20 odd years risking everything he had to prove a point _ that being freedom of expression.'' Lange was credited with persuading Eastman Kodak in the 1950s to change its policy of refusing to return pictures of nude people that were sent in for developing. Lange, whose photos have appeared in Time, Life, Vogue, and Harper's Bazaar, opened Elysium Fields in Topanga, west of Los Angeles, in 1967 and battled Los Angeles County to overturn its anti-nudity law. In 1968, a judge ruled that the law prohibiting disrobing on private property violated the right of self expression, free association, due process and equal protection under the law.
